title: Foresight bears fruit for young-gun winemaker
text:
They are all exquisite expressions of not only the granite soils in which they’re grown but also their maker’s deft touch in the cellar.

Mel Chester: "These four Estate wines are little time capsules. They really talk about our place, and the years we made them."

Chester credits her predecessor, French winemaker Gilles Lapalus, with great foresight in planting the two Italian grapes at Sutton Grange in the mid-2000s.

“Even in really hot weather like we had in 2018, fiano and aglianico cope well in the vineyard,” she says. “When shiraz vines are curling up, the fiano vines are still reaching for the sky. And it’s the same with the aglianico: the grapes have lots of tannin and high acidity; they love the heat and the dry.”

This is the first time this double set of Estate varietal wines has been released. Before Chester arrived at the vineyard, the initial trial planting of aglianico only ever yielded enough grapes to make small private bottlings.

Now that subsequent plantings have started to bear fruit, she can bottle a commercial – albeit very limited – quantity of the wine, and finally present a full representation of her work at Sutton Grange.

“These four Estate wines are little time capsules,” she says. “They really talk about our place, and the years we made them.”

The Sutton Grange vineyard is just one part of a 400-hectare farm established by Melbourne businessman and racing identity Peter Sidwell. The property also features an equestrian centre and Hereford cattle that devour the leftover grape stems and seeds and skins from the winery.

Chester says she enjoys the interconnected aspects of her job on the farm, from winemaking to helping to run a larger business. This involves working with marketing and events manager Jacqui Sidwell, the boss’s daughter who is the same age as Chester.

“I love being young and able to manage a business like this. Every week is different and challenging. And you see the results because you have to be held accountable for all of it. I sort of throw myself into things and hope there’s something I can learn.

“I like making money for the business, too. I like businesses to be successful, and being able to employ more people.

"That’s something I didn’t know I was going to enjoy as much as I do.”

Reviews

2018 Sutton Grange Estate Viognier

Bendigo $50

Whole-bunch pressed and carefully handled, this is an exquisite, delicate viognier, with a cool perfume of lilies and powdered ginger, and a fine, creamy texture that builds subtly on the tongue. Just gorgeous.

2017 Sutton Grange Estate Syrah

Bendigo $50

Sourced from the best blocks of shiraz on the property and fermented with a third whole bunches, this is a beautiful, elegant expression of the cooler vintage: pepper-fragrant, pure glossy purple fruit, silky tannins.

2018 Sutton Grange Estate Fiano

Bendigo $50

A number of factors, from low-yielding vines and small berries to wild fermentation in concrete egg and skin contact in barrel, all contribute to the mouth-filling complexity of this superbly rich fiano.

2017 Sutton Grange Estate Aglianico

Bendigo $60

Having been impressed by trial batches of this wine over the years, I’m happy to see it get a proper release: intense juicy black cherry and dried herb aromatics, and super-fine, lingering, umami-laced tannins.

The November issue of AFR Magazine, including the Young Rich List, is out on Friday, October 25 inside The Australian Financial Review. Follow AFR Mag on Twitter and Instagram.
description: Sutton Grange's Mel Chester has just bottled a commercial quantity of her finest work yet. And she’s only 30.
